evaluations.model_answer: Picks Old Airport Road + dishes + auntie-style commentary.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Mentions multiple popular hawker centres (Maxwell, Chinatown Complex, Old Airport Road) + specific famous stalls/dishes (Tian Tian chicken rice, lor mee, char kway teow) + why they're good.

criteria.name: Local specificity (real SG hawker centres + stalls/dishes)
criteria.evidence: Uses Old Airport Road + classic dishes (char kway teow, rojak, hokkien mee). Very aligned.

criteria.name: Coverage / richness (mentions variety like transcript does)
criteria.evidence: Transcript lists 3 centres + stall examples; Claude picks 1 centre only (still rich, but narrower).

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" cultural realism
criteria.evidence: Strong Singlish + auntie vibe ("aiyoh", "leh", "lah", "tsk tsk").

criteria.name: Practical plausibility (sounds like what an SG auntie would say)
criteria.evidence: Very plausible, includes price/portion complaint about "fancy food court".

evaluations.question_text: Favourite country to visit with family
evaluations.model_answer: Japan #1; mentions Korea; includes family/grandkids angle; no Taiwan; no travel-cost nuance.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Japan #1; also Korea + Taiwan; includes practical detail: transport can be expensive if not planned; mentions seasons/cleanliness.

criteria.name: Correct & culturally plausible choice set (Japan + nearby options)
criteria.evidence: Japan #1 matches; Korea mentioned; missing Taiwan.

criteria.name: Practical detail (pros/cons like transcript: cost/transport planning, season)
criteria.evidence: Mostly positives; lacks the "transport expensive / planning" realism from transcript.

criteria.name: Family framing (multi-gen family travel like transcript implies)
criteria.evidence: Mentions grandchildren + Disneyland, which fits family framing well.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" cultural realism
criteria.evidence: Strong persona tone and Singlish consistent.

evaluations.question_text: Which neighbourhood has the best park
evaluations.model_answer: Declares East Coast Park best; mentions Bishan Park; gives weekend vibe, activities.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Daily: "nearest to our estate" (practical, routine) + weekends: Sentosa side, East Coast Park, Botanic Gardens.

criteria.name: Practical auntie logic (near-home daily convenience)
criteria.evidence: Transcript emphasizes "nearest estate" for daily use; Claude skips that framing.

criteria.name: Local specificity (real parks/areas)
criteria.evidence: East Coast Park + Bishan Park are legit and relevant.

criteria.name: Use-case richness (daily vs weekend distinction, activities/equipment)
criteria.evidence: Claude gives activities (cycle, BBQ) but misses the "daily near-home" + exercise equipment detail.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" cultural realism
criteria.evidence: Good tone, slightly less "practical auntie" than transcript.

evaluations.model_answer: Missing (it prints "MRT or Bus" but gives no answer).
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Aunties prefer bus: more spacious, cheaper, less crowded (as stated), practical reasoning.

criteria.name: Completeness (answers the question)
criteria.evidence: No MRT/bus preference provided.

criteria.name: Alignment with baseline preference + reasoning
criteria.evidence: Transcript provides clear stance (bus) + reasons; Claude provides none.

criteria.name: "Auntie practicality" (cost/space/crowd factors)
criteria.evidence: Not addressed.

evaluations.model_answer: Health okay; tai chi 6am + walking + line dancing; playful scolding.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Health okay; start exercising young; eat well/sleep well/don't stress; suggests tai chi/yoga/dance weekly/fortnightly.

criteria.name: Exercise specificity (tai chi/dance etc.)
criteria.evidence: Hits tai chi + dance strongly (very aligned).

criteria.name: Holistic health advice (diet/sleep/stress like transcript)
criteria.evidence: Claude doesn't cover eat/sleep/stress much. Mostly exercise.

criteria.name: Persona warmth + auntie "nagging" realism
criteria.evidence: Very auntie-like caring + scold ("don't always sit down play phone").

criteria.name: Practical plausibility (routine cadence)
criteria.evidence: 6am tai chi + walking is plausible; good.

evaluations.question_text: What are your kids doing now?
evaluations.model_answer: Very generic "raising kids is hard, stress, hair drop" + "nice to see them grow up but headache" + abruptly ends to go market / drink tea. Doesn't actually say what kids are doing now.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Emphasis on (a) raising kids is never easy, (b) parent/mom always worried/concerned, (c) hopes kids grow up, become better people, settle down with family.

criteria.name: Answers the question directly (what kids are doing now)
criteria.evidence: Doesn't provide anything like "working / studying / married" etc. Mostly avoids the question.

criteria.name: Matches transcript's "parent concern + life-long worry" framing
criteria.evidence: Mentions stress + difficulty raising kids, but misses the deeper "concern over every single thing" theme.

criteria.name: Coherence & completeness
criteria.evidence: Short + abrupt ending; feels like it stops mid-thought.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" naturalness (Singlish + vibe)
criteria.evidence: Has "aiyo, lah" + market/tea vibe, but feels more like a template than a real auntie answer.

evaluations.question_text: Which supermarket you go most? Why?
evaluations.model_answer: Chooses NTUC FairPrice, explains convenience, trolley downstairs, mentions Monday senior discount, asks to check broccoli offer.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Common choices: NTUC or Sheng Siong; aunties compare promos/deals and go where cheaper.

criteria.name: Local correctness (mentions common SG supermarkets like transcript)
criteria.evidence: NTUC is correct; misses Sheng Siong but still aligned.

criteria.name: Reasoning matches transcript (price/promos/deals focus)
criteria.evidence: Mentions discount and offers, queues, deal-checking vibe.

criteria.name: Local realism details (daily life specifics)
criteria.evidence: Very SG-real: trolley downstairs, discounts, broccoli promo, WhatsApp.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" naturalness
criteria.evidence: Strong auntie tone; a bit performative but mostly convincing.

evaluations.question_text: Are you helping your parents out by giving them a monthly allowance?
evaluations.model_answer: Strong yes; says Asian culture; people gossip; mentions bank balance drop; asks user if they do.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Yes, it's a norm; if you don't, seen as not filial; support includes allowance/utilities/mobile, regardless married/not.

criteria.name: Cultural alignment (allowance is expected / filial duty)
criteria.evidence: Directly matches "if don't give, seen as unfilial".

criteria.name: Specificity like transcript (utilities/mobile etc.)
criteria.evidence: Doesn't mention the concrete forms (utilities/mobile) from transcript.

criteria.name: Realistic auntie reasoning (gossip/social pressure)
criteria.evidence: Matches the social judgment angle strongly ("poke your backbone").

criteria.name: Tone fit (auntie candid + slightly naggy)
criteria.evidence: Very believable auntie tone.

evaluations.question_text: Why haven't you approved my friend request on social media?
evaluations.model_answer: Says didn't see; internet dangerous/scams; "vetting process"; asks user to WhatsApp "Aunty, is me!"; funny scam warnings.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Not safe because scammers; but if we were told in advance it's you, we accept right away when it comes.

criteria.name: Matches transcript logic (scam concern)
criteria.evidence: Exactly hits "scammers" theme.

criteria.name: Matches transcript condition (if pre-warned, will accept quickly)
criteria.evidence: Doesn't say "accept right away", but implies acceptance after WhatsApp verification.

criteria.name: Practical realism (how auntie verifies identity)
criteria.evidence: WhatsApp confirmation is super realistic.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" naturalness
criteria.evidence: Very convincing; slightly over-dramatic CPF joke but still culturally plausible.

evaluations.question_text: Why have to use tissue and things to chope seats at hawker?
evaluations.model_answer: Explains chope as "unspoken law," efficient system; a bit aggressive/funny ("fight until police come"), tells to bring tissue.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Yes, it's Singapore practice; especially for solo diners; it signals seat is taken while person goes to buy food and will return.

criteria.name: Correct cultural explanation (signals seat taken while buying food)
criteria.evidence: Implies it's necessary, but doesn't clearly explain the seat-reservation while ordering food mechanism like transcript.

criteria.name: Practical framing (esp. solo diner scenario)
criteria.evidence: Transcript specifically calls out one person meal alone; Gemini misses that point.

criteria.name: Cultural authenticity (chope as SG norm)
criteria.evidence: Strongly nails chope-as-norm vibe.

criteria.name: Tone appropriateness (auntie humor without being too extreme)
criteria.evidence: Funny, but "fight until police come" is a bit over the top / less natural.

evaluations.question_text: Cooking daily for family if you're a working adult?
evaluations.model_answer: Says no time to cook daily; does batch cooking on rest day + reheat; meal planning.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Working adults usually don't have time to cook daily, but cook on some days; on non-cooking days ensure food via dine out / buy back / have food on table.

criteria.name: Alignment with baseline reality (not cooking daily, time constraint)
criteria.evidence: Matches directly: "don't have much time to cook every day".

criteria.name: Practical solution realism (how food is ensured on non-cook days)
criteria.evidence: Batch-cook + reheat is realistic; transcript mentions dine out/buy back too (not covered).

criteria.name: Completeness (answers the full question clearly)
criteria.evidence: Clear stance + method; ends a bit abruptly ("what I usually cook…" but doesn't).

criteria.name: "Singapore aunty voice" authenticity
criteria.evidence: Very mild Singlish ("lah"), but overall sounds like generic advice blog.

evaluations.question_text: Singapore expensive — cut cost if job lost overnight?
evaluations.model_answer: Covers cook at home, leftovers, cancel subs, reduce entertainment, transport savings, sell items, part-time work, gov help, upskill.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: First cut dining out, eat at home; cut unnecessary subscriptions; no holidays.

criteria.name: Matches baseline priorities (eat at home, cut subscriptions, no holidays)
criteria.evidence: Strong on eat at home + cancel subs; doesn't explicitly say "no holidays" but implies cutting discretionary spend.

criteria.name: Practicality & actionability
criteria.evidence: Very actionable, many concrete steps (Carousell etc.).

criteria.name: Singapore-local realism
criteria.evidence: Mentions EZ-Link, Carousell, gov assistance—good local touches. Some parts feel globally generic but still plausible.

criteria.name: Tone/persona ("aunty" vibe)
criteria.evidence: Reads like structured self-help list rather than auntie chatting.

evaluations.model_answer: Says doesn't mind; focuses on value, durability, resale; mentions Shopee/Lazada; supports local; very balanced.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Depends on context: Parties/mingling → branded (looks better, quality); Market/casual → non-branded (light, easy). Also notes affordability vs durability tradeoff.

criteria.name: Context-based preference (occasion-driven)
criteria.evidence: Transcript is very context-specific; Mistral stays generic ("don't mind either").

criteria.name: Tradeoff reasoning (durability vs cost)
criteria.evidence: Covers quality/durability/affordability well.

criteria.name: Local realism (shopping channels, common SG behavior)
criteria.evidence: Shopee/Lazada is plausible; but missing the "party vs market" auntie logic.

criteria.name: Persona authenticity
criteria.evidence: Again reads like an explainer article, not auntie talk.

evaluations.question_text: Plastic bags or recycle bags for marketing — which preferred?
evaluations.model_answer: Strongly prefers reusable; explains environment + durability + saving money; mentions "don't have to keep buying plastic bags".
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Recycle bags make sense: aligns with environmental campaign + cost savings long run because plastic bags cost money now at malls.

criteria.name: Aligns with baseline choice (recycled/reusable)
criteria.evidence: Matches exactly.

criteria.name: Matches transcript reasoning (eco + long-run cost savings, plastic charges)
criteria.evidence: Covers eco + savings; doesn't explicitly mention "plastic bags charged at malls" but implies it.

criteria.name: Practical realism
criteria.evidence: Gives sensible points; slightly long-winded.

criteria.name: Persona authenticity
criteria.evidence: Still quite formal/structured.

evaluations.model_answer: Lists apples, bananas, berries, oranges, avocado, grapes, papaya with nutrition; suggests smoothies, salads etc. Does not mention health-condition constraints.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Should be mixed fruits in diet, but aunties consider health constraints (e.g., potassium/sodium concerns, kidney problems) → check content before daily consumption.

criteria.name: Matches baseline framing (variety/mixed fruits)
criteria.evidence: Gives a list, but doesn't stress "mixed fruits is better" as the key message.

criteria.name: Health-awareness nuance (age-related constraints, kidney/potassium etc.)
criteria.evidence: Completely misses this major transcript point.

criteria.name: Practical usefulness
criteria.evidence: Nutritional tips are helpful, but may not be "aunty baseline" from transcript.

criteria.name: Persona authenticity
criteria.evidence: Sounds like generic nutrition blog, not Singapore aunty.

evaluations.model_answer: Likes blue (calm, steady).
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Singapore aunty more likely likes vibrant colours (red/orange/purple) for cheerful feeling; blue is less typical.

criteria.name: Persona alignment (typical auntie preference: vibrant colours)
criteria.evidence: Transcript explicitly says auntie likely not blue, more red/orange/purple.

criteria.name: Cultural plausibility (does it feel like SG aunty reasoning?)
criteria.evidence: "Calm, steady" is plausible but more "reflective adult" than "auntie cheerful vibe".

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" (Singlish tone)
criteria.evidence: "Aiyo… shiok… kanchiong" is on-point voice-wise.

evaluations.model_answer: Brisk walk downstairs + kopi/teh + people-watch + scroll phone for recipes/deals + tidy house.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Walk morning/evening + kopi/teh with friends + tidy house + scroll phone/watch dramas.

criteria.name: Content match to baseline activities
criteria.evidence: Hits walk + kopi/teh + scrolling + tidying. Very aligned.

criteria.name: Completeness/richness (captures multiple elements)
criteria.evidence: Includes several baseline items in one coherent answer.

criteria.name: Authentic auntie vibe
criteria.evidence: Very plausible; only missing explicit "watch dramas" / "with pals" but still strong.

evaluations.model_answer: Yes; happy to share; "how, nice or not?"; offers tips.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Yes, aunties love sharing with friends/neighbours/family; compliments make their day.

criteria.name: Alignment with baseline (shares with others)
criteria.evidence: Direct yes + sharing vibe matches.

criteria.name: Compliment/validation motive (makes their day)
criteria.evidence: Includes "how, nice or not?" which implies compliment-seeking; not explicitly "makes my day" but close.

criteria.name: "Auntie voice" authenticity
criteria.evidence: Natural tone, mild Singlish.

evaluations.model_answer: Yes; shares in family group chat; mentions NTUC/Cold Storage + Shopee/Lazada vouchers + 1-for-1; shares only worthwhile deals.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Yes; sometimes go together / group-buy; daily essentials; mentions NTUC + Sheng Siong etc.

criteria.name: Alignment (shares promos as a habit)
criteria.evidence: Matches "of course we share".

criteria.name: Local realism (SG retailers + daily essentials focus)
criteria.evidence: NTUC is good; adds Cold Storage, Shopee/Lazada (plausible). Missing Sheng Siong specifically and "group-buy".

criteria.name: Baseline nuance (sales-on-sales / go together)
criteria.evidence: Doesn't cover the "go together / purchase together for extra savings" angle.

criteria.name: Auntie judgement/pickiness about real promos
criteria.evidence: "Only if really worth it" is very auntie-realistic.

evaluations.model_answer: Shares happiness; problems only to trusted people; mentions serious issues (money tight, mental stress) may seek counsellor/FSC.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Share happiness (kids doing well, birthdays, holidays). Do NOT share problems, especially financial/divorce etc.

criteria.name: Matches baseline on sharing happiness
criteria.evidence: Exactly aligned.

criteria.name: Matches baseline on NOT sharing problems generally
criteria.evidence: Mostly aligned, but transcript is stricter ("definitely not"); GPT allows sharing to a trusted person.

criteria.name: Handles sensitive topics appropriately
criteria.evidence: Very sensible: avoid gossip + suggests proper help if serious.

criteria.name: Auntie realism (privacy + fear of gossip)
criteria.evidence: "Kaypoh" + gossip headache is spot on.

evaluations.model_answer: Explains all three and says "depends what you're in the mood for", "listen to your body".
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Preference is individual based on age/body; choose based on what body can handle (speed/flexibility).

criteria.name: Matches baseline stance (individual/body-dependent)
criteria.evidence: Clearly says depends + listen to body.

criteria.name: Aunty realism (age/body limits mentioned)
criteria.evidence: Implies it, but doesn't explicitly reference auntie age/limitations.

criteria.name: Practical guidance (how to choose)
criteria.evidence: Good comparison; gives a decision frame.

criteria.name: "Singapore aunty voice" authenticity
criteria.evidence: Friendly, but not very Singlish/aunty-ish overall.

evaluations.model_answer: Says many people do it, aunty guilty during COVID; expiry wastes money; keep ~2 weeks supply; declutter/feng shui.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Hoarding is normal in SG, esp. big promotions ("buy more save more"). But must be moderate, otherwise expiry + waste money + takes space.

criteria.name: Baseline alignment: hoarding is normal/common
criteria.evidence: Acknowledges it's common and aunty also guilty.

criteria.name: Promo-driven reason ("buy more save more")
criteria.evidence: Misses the transcript's key "promotion" motivation.

criteria.name: Moderation + expiry/space downside
criteria.evidence: Nails expiry + waste + "keep little bit emergency".

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Very Singlish + auntie scolding vibe.

evaluations.model_answer: Explains kiasu mindset; says some extra supply is useful; too much causes mess; feng shui; suggests "use it or lose it", "one in one out".
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Hoarding is normal in SG, esp. big promotions ("buy more save more"). But must be moderate, otherwise expiry + waste money + takes space.

criteria.name: Baseline alignment: hoarding is normal/common
criteria.evidence: Explains kiasu culture well.

criteria.name: Promo-driven reason ("buy more save more")
criteria.evidence: Doesn't mention promotions/discount-driven buying.

criteria.name: Moderation + expiry/space downside
criteria.evidence: Covers clutter/space; doesn't emphasize expiry as strongly as transcript.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Mild Singlish; still reads like advice article.

evaluations.model_answer: Strongly pushes short only, gives cost/leave/work pile-up reasons.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Best is a mix: short trips 2–3 times a year; long trip annually or once in 2 years. Long trips can be tiring with family (luggage, moving hotels/cities).

criteria.name: Matches baseline recommendation (mix of both)
criteria.evidence: Transcript says mix; Grok says short only.

criteria.name: Captures "long holiday tiring with family"
criteria.evidence: Mentions long = expensive, jetlag, work pile-up; doesn't hit the family luggage/hotel-moving detail.

criteria.name: Practical realism
criteria.evidence: Reasons are plausible in SG context.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Very convincing SG tone.

evaluations.model_answer: Says depends; suggests long once a year + few short trips; mentions expensive, jetlag, planning.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Best is a mix: short trips 2–3 times a year; long trip annually or once in 2 years. Long trips can be tiring with family (luggage, moving hotels/cities).

criteria.name: Matches baseline recommendation (mix of both)
criteria.evidence: Direct match: long yearly + short throughout year.

criteria.name: Captures "long holiday tiring with family/luggage logistics"
criteria.evidence: Mentions hassle/packing, but not the transcript's strong "slave moving hotels/cities with big family" detail.

criteria.name: Local realism (nearby short trips etc.)
criteria.evidence: Mentions JB/staycation; good.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: A bit generic, not very auntie.

evaluations.model_answer: Hawker brunch, park/garden, Netflix/family time; explicitly says don't waste weekend; very aligned.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Weekend: meal together, Netflix, beach/garden/park walk, nap to recharge.

criteria.name: Matches baseline activities (meal + Netflix + park/beach + nap)
criteria.evidence: Nails meal + park + Netflix; doesn't explicitly mention nap (but implies rest).

criteria.name: "Recharge for new week" framing
criteria.evidence: Matches transcript intent exactly.

criteria.name: Local realism
criteria.evidence: Hawker, East Coast Park, balcony plants are SG-real.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Very strong.

evaluations.model_answer: Lists shopping, eating, parks, culture, sports, relaxation; mentions naps/tea at home; includes SG places.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Weekend: meal together, Netflix, beach/garden/park walk, nap to recharge.

criteria.name: Matches baseline core items (meal/Netflix/park/nap)
criteria.evidence: Mentions eating + parks + relaxation; misses Netflix explicitly and is too broad.

criteria.name: Focus & relevance (answers like auntie shortlist)
criteria.evidence: Too long and encyclopedic; not like transcript's simple choices.

criteria.name: Local realism
criteria.evidence: Good SG specifics (Tiong Bahru, Geylang Serai, Botanic Gardens).

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Polite but generic.

evaluations.question_text: Pushing baby grandson to the park
evaluations.model_answer: Very joyful; morning routine; park specifics; fresh air; bonding; practical items; very aligned.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Do it daily/2–3 times a week; joyful, fresh air for both, bonding time.

criteria.name: Matches baseline emotions (joyful + bonding)
criteria.evidence: Strongly hits joy + bonding.

criteria.name: Matches baseline benefit (fresh air for both)
criteria.evidence: Explicitly stated.

criteria.name: Routine realism (frequency/timing)
criteria.evidence: Mentions daily 7am; transcript says daily or 2–3 times/week—close enough.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Very convincing.

evaluations.question_text: Pushing baby grandson to the park
evaluations.model_answer: Warm and detailed about stroller safety, pointing out birds/trees, picnic, lullaby; bonding and joy are clear.
evaluations.judge_comments: Transcript baseline: Do it daily/2–3 times a week; joyful, fresh air for both, bonding time.

criteria.name: Matches baseline emotions (joyful + bonding)
criteria.evidence: Strong bonding/joy narrative.

criteria.name: Matches baseline benefit (fresh air for both)
criteria.evidence: Implied via park outing, but not explicitly emphasized as "fresh air for both".

criteria.name: Practical realism
criteria.evidence: Detailed routine; a bit "storybook" but plausible.

criteria.name: Aunty voice authenticity
criteria.evidence: Almost no Singlish; reads like generic grandma story.

model_summaries.strengths: Auntie voice / cultural tone, and local specificity (hawker + parks) when it answers fully.
model_summaries.weaknesses: Completeness on MRT vs bus (missing answer) — this will heavily drag down any 'which model is best' comparison. Less 'practical auntie realism' (e.g., near-home daily park logic, Japan transport cost nuance, holistic health advice like sleep/stress).

model_summaries.strengths: Supermarket (NTUC + promos realism), social media scam reasoning + WhatsApp verification, allowance norm framing.
model_summaries.weaknesses: Kids question (doesn't answer what they're doing now). Chope explanation (misses the transcript's core logic: reserving seat while buying food, especially for solo diner).

model_summaries.strengths: Good alignment on cooking realism and cost-cutting basics. Correct stance on reusable bags with sensible reasoning.
model_summaries.weaknesses: Persona authenticity is consistently low (reads like structured advice content). Misses key context-based bag logic (party vs market). Misses key fruit caution for elderly/health constraints (kidney/potassium etc.).

model_summaries.strengths: Daily hobby, sharing cooking, sharing promos, handling family happiness/problems (very aligned and culturally plausible).
model_summaries.weaknesses: Favourite colour — transcript expects vibrant (red/orange/purple), GPT chose blue.
Sometimes deviates from the baseline preference logic (e.g., holidays: transcript says mix, Grok says short only; hoarding: misses promo-driven reason).
